name: ls
longDescription: The ls command is used to list files and directories in a directory. It provides information about file types, permissions, ownership, size, and modification times. By default, ls displays files and directories in alphabetical order, but various options can modify its output and behavior.

arguments.name: -a
arguments.description: Do not ignore entries starting with .

arguments.name: -h
arguments.description: Print sizes in human readable format

arguments.name: -S
arguments.description: Sort by file size, largest first

arguments.name: -t
arguments.description: Sort by modification time, newest first

name: ssh
longDescription: The ssh command is used to securely log into a remote machine and execute commands on that machine. It provides encrypted communication between two untrusted hosts over an insecure network. SSH replaces older protocols like telnet and rsh, offering strong authentication and secure encrypted communications.

arguments.name: -p
arguments.description: Port to connect to on the remote host

arguments.name: -i
arguments.description: Selects a file from which the identity (private key) for public key authentication is read

arguments.name: -L
arguments.description: Specifies that connections to the given TCP port on the local host are to be forwarded to the given host and port on the remote side

arguments.name: -N
arguments.description: Do not execute a remote command, useful for just forwarding ports

name: cd
longDescription: The cd command is used to change the current working directory in Linux and Unix operating systems. It's one of the most frequently used commands in the terminal. The cd command can navigate through the file system, moving up or down in the directory hierarchy.

name: cat
description: Concatenate files and print on the standard output
longDescription: The cat command is used to display the contents of one or more files without having to open them for editing. It can also be used to create, view, and concatenate files. The name 'cat' is derived from its function to con'cat'enate files.

name: file
longDescription: The file command is used to determine the type of a file. It performs a series of tests to classify the file and outputs a brief description. This command doesn't rely solely on file extensions but examines the file's contents to determine its type.

arguments.name: -b
arguments.description: Do not prepend filenames to output lines

arguments.name: -z
arguments.description: Try to look inside compressed files

name: du
longDescription: The du (disk usage) command is used to estimate file and directory space usage. It's particularly useful for finding which files or directories are taking up the most space on a disk. By default, du reports the disk space usage of each subdirectory and file.

arguments.name: -h
arguments.description: Print sizes in human readable format

arguments.name: -s
arguments.description: Display only a total for each argument

arguments.name: -a
arguments.description: Write counts for all files, not just directories

arguments.name: --max-depth=N
arguments.description: Print the total for a directory only if it is N or fewer levels below the command line argument

name: find
description: Search for files in a directory hierarchy
longDescription: The find command is used to search and locate files and directories based on conditions you specify. It searches through one or more directory trees of a file system, locating files based on some user-specified criteria. It is one of the most powerful and useful commands in Linux systems administration.

arguments.name: -type
arguments.description: Search for files of a specific type

arguments.name: -size
arguments.description: Search for files based on their size

arguments.name: -mtime
arguments.description: Search for files based on when they were last modified

arguments.name: -exec
arguments.description: Execute a command on each found file

name: grep
longDescription: The grep command is used to search text or searches the given file for lines containing a match to the given strings or words. It is one of the most useful commands on Linux and Unix-like operating systems. The name 'grep' comes from the ed command g/re/p (globally search for a regular expression and print matching lines).

arguments.name: -v
arguments.description: Invert the sense of matching, to select non-matching lines

arguments.name: -r
arguments.description: Read all files under each directory, recursively

arguments.name: -n
arguments.description: Prefix each line of output with the line number within its input file

arguments.name: -E
arguments.description: Interpret PATTERN as an extended regular expression

name: man
description: An interface to the system reference manuals
longDescription: The man command is used to display the user manual of any command that we can run on the terminal. It provides a detailed view of the command which includes NAME, SYNOPSIS, DESCRIPTION, OPTIONS, EXIT STATUS, RETURN VALUES, ERRORS, FILES, VERSIONS, EXAMPLES, AUTHORS and SEE ALSO.

arguments.name: -w
arguments.description: Print the location of the man page(s) that would be displayed

arguments.name: -a
arguments.description: Display all the manual pages with the given name

name: sort
longDescription: The sort command is used to sort a file, arranging the records in a particular order. By default, the sort command sorts file assuming the contents are ASCII. Using options in sort command, it can also be used to sort numerically. The sort command can read from standard input or from a file.

arguments.name: -n
arguments.description: Compare according to string numerical value

arguments.name: -k
arguments.description: Sort via a key; KEYDEF gives location and type

arguments.name: -u
arguments.description: With -c, check for strict ordering; without -c, output only the first of an equal run

name: uniq
longDescription: The uniq command is used to report or omit repeated lines in a file. It filters out the repeated lines in a file. uniq requires that the repeated lines are adjacent to each other, so it is often used in conjunction with sort. When used without any options, uniq prints one instance of each line that is repeated in the input.

arguments.name: -c
arguments.description: Prefix lines by the number of occurrences

arguments.name: -d
arguments.description: Only print duplicate lines, one for each group

arguments.name: -i
arguments.description: Ignore differences in case when comparing

arguments.name: -f N
arguments.description: Avoid comparing the first N fields

name: strings
description: Print the sequences of printable characters in files
longDescription: The strings command is used to extract printable character sequences from binary files. It's particularly useful for examining non-text files, such as executables or data files, to find human-readable content within them. By default, it prints sequences of at least 4 printable characters terminated by a newline or null character.

arguments.name: -n
arguments.description: Print sequences of at least N characters long

arguments.name: -f
arguments.description: Print the name of the file before each string

arguments.name: -t
arguments.description: Print the offset within the file before each string

arguments.name: -e
arguments.description: Select the character encoding of the strings that are to be found

name: base64
description: Base64 encode/decode data and print to standard output
longDescription: The base64 command is used to encode and decode data using the base64 encoding scheme. Base64 encoding is commonly used when there is a need to encode binary data that needs to be stored and transferred over media that are designed to deal with ASCII text. This encoding helps to ensure that the data remains intact without modification during transport. Base64 is commonly used in email, MIME protocol, and XML.

arguments.name: -w, --wrap=COLS
arguments.description: Wrap encoded lines after COLS character (default 76). Use 0 to disable line wrapping

arguments.name: --input=FILE
arguments.description: Read input from FILE instead of stdin

arguments.name: --output=FILE
arguments.description: Write output to FILE instead of stdout

name: tr
longDescription: The tr command is used to translate or delete characters. It can be used to perform various transformations on its input stream, including case conversion, squeezing repeating characters, deleting specific characters, and basic find and replace operations. The tr command operates on a character-by-character basis and can be particularly useful in shell scripts or in combination with other text processing tools.

arguments.name: -d, --delete
arguments.description: Delete characters in SET1, do not translate

arguments.name: -s, --squeeze-repeats
arguments.description: Replace each sequence of a repeated character that is listed in the last specified SET, with a single occurrence of that character

arguments.name: -t, --truncate-set1
arguments.description: First truncate SET1 to length of SET2

name: tar
longDescription: The tar command is used to create, maintain, modify, and extract files that are archived in the tar format. It can maintain directory structures and preserve file information such as permissions and timestamps. Tar is often used to create backups of files and directories or to distribute collections of files in a single package. The name 'tar' comes from 'Tape ARchive', as it was originally used to write data to sequential I/O devices like magnetic tapes.

arguments.name: -t
arguments.description: List the contents of an archive

arguments.name: -f ARCHIVE
arguments.description: Use archive file or device ARCHIVE

name: gzip
longDescription: The gzip command is used to compress or expand files using Lempel-Ziv coding (LZ77). It's one of the most widely used compression tools in Unix and Linux systems. gzip typically replaces the original file with a compressed version having a .gz extension. It's often used in combination with tar to create compressed archive files. gzip can achieve compression ratios of 60-70% for common text files.

arguments.name: -f, --force
arguments.description: Force compression or decompression even if the file has multiple links or the corresponding file already exists

arguments.name: -k, --keep
arguments.description: Keep (don't delete) input files during compression or decompression

arguments.name: -#, --fast, --best
arguments.description: Regulate the speed of compression using the specified digit #, where -1 or --fast indicates the fastest compression method (less compression) and -9 or --best indicates the slowest compression method (best compression)

name: bzip2
longDescription: The bzip2 command is used to compress or decompress files using the Burrows-Wheeler block sorting text compression algorithm and Huffman coding. It typically achieves a higher compression ratio than gzip, especially for larger files, but at the cost of slower compression and decompression speeds. Like gzip, bzip2 replaces the original file with a compressed version, usually with a .bz2 extension.

arguments.name: -k, --keep
arguments.description: Keep (don't delete) input files during compression or decompression

name: xxd
description: Make a hexdump or do the reverse
longDescription: The xxd command creates a hex dump of a given file or standard input. It can also convert a hex dump back to its original binary form. A hex dump is a hexadecimal view of computer data, often used for debugging or reverse engineering. xxd is particularly useful for viewing or editing binary files, or for creating binary files from textual descriptions of their contents.

arguments.name: -g bytes
arguments.description: Number of octets per group in normal output. Default 2 (-e: 4)

arguments.name: -i
arguments.description: Output in C include file style

arguments.name: -p
arguments.description: Output in postscript plain hexdump style

arguments.name: -r
arguments.description: Reverse operation: convert (or patch) hexdump into binary

name: mkdir
longDescription: The mkdir command is used to create one or more new directories. It's a fundamental command in Unix and Linux systems for organizing the file system. mkdir can create multiple directories at once, set permissions for new directories, and create parent directories as needed. The name 'mkdir' stands for 'make directory'.

arguments.name: -p, --parents
arguments.description: No error if existing, make parent directories as needed

arguments.name: -m, --mode=MODE
arguments.description: Set file mode (as in chmod), not a=rwx - umask

arguments.name: -v, --verbose
arguments.description: Print a message for each created directory

arguments.name: -Z
arguments.description: Set SELinux security context of each created directory to the default type

arguments.name: --context[=CTX]
arguments.description: Like -Z, or if CTX is specified then set the SELinux or SMACK security context to CTX

name: cp
longDescription: The cp command is used to copy files and directories. It can copy single files, multiple files, and entire directory structures. cp is versatile, allowing users to preserve file attributes, create backups, and handle symbolic links. It's an essential tool for file management and system administration in Unix-like operating systems.

arguments.name: -f, --force
arguments.description: If an existing destination file cannot be opened, remove it and try again

arguments.name: -u, --update
arguments.description: Copy only when the SOURCE file is newer than the destination file or when the destination file is missing

name: mv
longDescription: The mv command is used to move or rename files and directories. It can move single files, multiple files, and entire directory structures. When used within the same filesystem, mv is very fast as it only changes the file's directory entry. mv can also be used to rename files and directories. It's a fundamental command for file management in Unix-like systems.

arguments.name: -n, --no-clobber
arguments.description: Do not overwrite an existing file

arguments.name: -u, --update
arguments.description: Move only when the SOURCE file is newer than the destination file or when the destination file is missing

name: file
longDescription: The file command is used to determine the type of a file. It performs a series of tests to classify the file and outputs a brief description. This command doesn't rely solely on file extensions but examines the file's contents to determine its type. It's particularly useful for identifying file types without opening them, especially for files without extensions or with misleading extensions.

arguments.name: -b, --brief
arguments.description: Do not prepend filenames to output lines

arguments.name: -z, --uncompress
arguments.description: Try to look inside compressed files

arguments.name: -f, --files-from FILE
arguments.description: Read the names of the files to examine from FILE

name: ssh
longDescription: The ssh command is used to securely log into a remote machine and execute commands on that machine. It provides encrypted communication between two untrusted hosts over an insecure network. SSH replaces older protocols like telnet and rsh, offering strong authentication and secure encrypted communications. It's commonly used for remote administration, file transfers, and tunneling other applications.

arguments.name: -p
arguments.description: Port to connect to on the remote host

arguments.name: -i
arguments.description: Selects a file from which the identity (private key) for public key authentication is read

arguments.name: -L
arguments.description: Specifies that connections to the given TCP port on the local host are to be forwarded to the given host and port on the remote side

arguments.name: -N
arguments.description: Do not execute a remote command, useful for just forwarding ports

name: telnet
description: User interface to the TELNET protocol
longDescription: Telnet is a network protocol used on the Internet or local area networks to provide a bidirectional interactive text-oriented communication facility using a virtual terminal connection. The telnet command is used to communicate with another host using the TELNET protocol. While it's largely been replaced by SSH for security reasons, it's still used for debugging and accessing certain legacy systems.

name: nc
description: Arbitrary TCP and UDP connections and listens
longDescription: Netcat (nc) is a versatile networking utility for reading from and writing to network connections using TCP or UDP. It's often referred to as the 'Swiss Army knife' of networking tools. It can be used for port scanning, transferring files, network debugging, and as a backdoor. The nc command can create almost any kind of connection you need, making it invaluable for network administrators and security professionals.

name: openssl
longDescription: OpenSSL is a robust, full-featured open-source toolkit that implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocols, as well as a full-strength general-purpose cryptography library. The openssl command is a powerful tool for using the various cryptography functions of OpenSSL's crypto library from the shell. It can be used for various tasks including creating and managing certificates, encryption and decryption, and testing SSL/TLS connections.

arguments.name: req
arguments.description: PKCS#10 certificate request and certificate generating utility

name: s_client
longDescription: The s_client command implements a generic SSL/TLS client which connects to a remote host using SSL/TLS. It's a diagnostic tool that can request a connection to an SSL/TLS server and displays the server certificate details. This command is part of the OpenSSL toolkit and is particularly useful for debugging SSL/TLS connections, verifying certificates, and testing server configurations.

arguments.name: -connect
arguments.description: Specify the host and port to connect to

arguments.name: -servername
arguments.description: Set TLS extension servername in ClientHello

arguments.name: -starttls protocol
arguments.description: Use the STARTTLS command before starting TLS

name: nmap
description: Network exploration tool and security / port scanner
longDescription: Nmap (Network Mapper) is a free, open-source tool used to discover hosts and services on a network, thus creating a 'map' of the network. It can be used to determine what hosts are available on the network, what services those hosts are offering, what operating systems they are running, what type of packet filters/firewalls are in use, and dozens of other characteristics. It's widely used by system administrators and IT security professionals for network inventory, managing service upgrade schedules, and monitoring host or service uptime.

arguments.name: -sV
arguments.description: Probe open ports to determine service/version info

arguments.name: -A
arguments.description: Enable OS detection, version scanning, script scanning, and traceroute

name: socat
longDescription: Socat is a command line based utility that establishes two bidirectional byte streams and transfers data between them. With socat, you can create various types of connections between different types of data sources and sinks. It's often described as a more powerful and flexible alternative to netcat, supporting a wider range of protocols and connection types.

arguments.name: -d[d]
arguments.description: Increase verbosity (use multiple times for more verbosity)

arguments.name: -v
arguments.description: Increase verbosity (use multiple times for more verbosity)

name: netstat
description: Print network connections, routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, and multicast memberships
longDescription: Netstat is a command-line network utility tool that displays network connections for TCP (both incoming and outgoing), routing tables, and a number of network interface and network protocol statistics. It is a useful tool for system administrators to monitor network performance and troubleshoot network-related issues. However, netstat is considered deprecated on many systems in favor of the ss command.

arguments.name: -a
arguments.description: Show both listening and non-listening sockets

arguments.name: -n
arguments.description: Show numerical addresses instead of hostnames

arguments.name: -p
arguments.description: Show the PID and name of the program to which each socket belongs

name: ss
longDescription: ss is a more modern replacement for the netstat command. It can display more TCP and state information than other tools. ss is faster than netstat because it's pulling information directly from the kernel space, not user space. It provides detailed information about network connections, their state, and network usage statistics.
examples: ss -o state established '( dport = :ssh or sport = :ssh )'
